Problem 4

Prove that the natural logarithm function is real analytic on (0,+∞)\p{0, +\infty}(0,+∞).

Solution.

Let a>0a > 0a>0. By the geometric series, we have

1x=1a⋅11+x−aa=1a∑n=0∞(−x−aa)n=∑n=0∞(−1)nan+1(x−a)n,\frac{1}{x} = \frac{1}{a} \cdot \frac{1}{1 + \frac{x-a}{a}} = \frac{1}{a} \sum_{n=0}^\infty \p{-\frac{x - a}{a}}^n = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{\p{-1}^n}{a^{n+1}} \p{x - a}^n,x1​=a1​⋅1+ax−a​1​=a1​n=0∑∞​(−ax−a​)n=n=0∑∞​an+1(−1)n​(x−a)n,

and this equality is valid for ∣x−aa∣<1  ⟺  ∣x−a∣<a  ⟺  x∈(0,2a)\abs{\frac{x - a}{a}} < 1 \iff \abs{x - a} < a \iff x \in \p{0, 2a}∣∣​ax−a​∣∣​<1⟺∣x−a∣<a⟺x∈(0,2a). In other words, 1x\frac{1}{x}x1​ is real analytic at aaa with radius of convergence aaa. Moreover, if ∣x−a∣<a\abs{x - a} < a∣x−a∣<a, then [a,x]\br{a, x}[a,x] (or [x,a]\br{x, a}[x,a], if x<ax < ax<a) is a subset of (0,2a)\p{0, 2a}(0,2a). Thus, the equality at (∗*∗) below is valid for these xxx's.

log⁡x=log⁡a+∫ax1t dt=log⁡a+∫ax∑n=0∞(−1)nan+1(t−a)n dt=log⁡a+∑n=0∞∫ax(−1)nan+1(t−a)n dt(∗)=log⁡a+∑n=0∞(−1)nan+1(n+1)(x−a)n+1=log⁡a+∑n=1∞(−1)n−1ann(x−a)n.\begin{aligned} \log x &= \log a + \int_a^x \frac{1}{t} \,\diff{t} \\ &= \log a + \int_a^x \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{\p{-1}^n}{a^{n+1}} \p{t - a}^n \,\diff{t} \\ &= \log a + \sum_{n=0}^\infty \int_a^x \frac{\p{-1}^n}{a^{n+1}} \p{t - a}^n \,\diff{t} && \p{*} \\ &= \log a + \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{\p{-1}^n}{a^{n+1}\p{n + 1}} \p{x - a}^{n+1} \\ &= \log a + \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{\p{-1}^{n-1}}{a^n n} \p{x - a}^n. \end{aligned}logx​=loga+∫ax​t1​dt=loga+∫ax​n=0∑∞​an+1(−1)n​(t−a)ndt=loga+n=0∑∞​∫ax​an+1(−1)n​(t−a)ndt=loga+n=0∑∞​an+1(n+1)(−1)n​(x−a)n+1=loga+n=1∑∞​ann(−1)n−1​(x−a)n.​​(∗)​

Thus, for x∈(0,2a)x \in \p{0, 2a}x∈(0,2a), we have log⁡x=∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n\log x = \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n\p{x - a}^nlogx=∑n=0∞​cn​(x−a)n, where

cn={log⁡aif n=0,(−1)n−1annif n>1.,c_n = \begin{dcases} \log a & \text{if } n = 0, \\[1ex] \frac{\p{-1}^{n-1}}{a^n n} & \text{if } n > 1. \end{dcases},cn​=⎩⎨⎧​logaann(−1)n−1​​if n=0,if n>1.​,

so log⁡x\log xlogx is real analytic at aaa. Since aaa was arbitrary, this shows that log⁡x\log xlogx is real analytic on (0,+∞)\p{0, +\infty}(0,+∞).

Problem 6

Let m>0m > 0m>0 be an integer. Show that

lim⁡x→+∞exxm=+∞.\lim_{x\to+\infty} \frac{e^x}{x^m} = +\infty.x→+∞lim​xmex​=+∞.

(Hint: what happens to the ratio between ex+1/(x+1)me^{x+1}/\p{x+1}^mex+1/(x+1)m and ex/xme^x/x^mex/xm as x→+∞x \to +\inftyx→+∞?)

Solution.

Following the hint, we have

lim⁡x→+∞ex+1(x+1)m/exxm=lim⁡x→+∞e(xx+1)m=e.\lim_{x\to+\infty} \left. \frac{e^{x+1}}{\p{x+1}^m} \middle/ \frac{e^x}{x^m} \right. = \lim_{x\to+\infty} e \p{\frac{x}{x + 1}}^m = e.x→+∞lim​(x+1)mex+1​/xmex​=x→+∞lim​e(x+1x​)m=e.

In particular, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that if x≥Nx \geq Nx≥N, then ex+1(x+1)m≥2exxm\frac{e^{x+1}}{\p{x+1}^m} \geq 2 \frac{e^x}{x^m}(x+1)mex+1​≥2xmex​. Lastly, notice that

ddxexxm=xmex−mxm−1exx2m=xm−1ex(x−m)x2m,\frac{\diff}{\diff x} \frac{e^x}{x^m} = \frac{x^m e^x - mx^{m-1} e^x}{x^{2m}} = \frac{x^{m-1} e^x \p{x - m}}{x^{2m}},dxd​xmex​=x2mxmex−mxm−1ex​=x2mxm−1ex(x−m)​,

so exxm\frac{e^x}{x^m}xmex​ is strictly increasing if x>mx > mx>m. Putting everything together, if x≥2N+m+1x \geq 2N + m + 1x≥2N+m+1, then

exxm≥2Nex−N(x−N)m≥2Nem+1(m+1)m,\frac{e^x}{x^m} \geq 2^N \frac{e^{x - N}}{\p{x - N}^m} \geq 2^N \frac{e^{m + 1}}{\p{m + 1}^m},xmex​≥2N(x−N)mex−N​≥2N(m+1)mem+1​,

where we used x−N>m+1x - N > m + 1x−N>m+1. Since 2N→∞2^N \to \infty2N→∞ as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞, this completes the proof.
